body: This is related to #2850, but I'm going to leave this open so we can separate the parsing/signing components here.
This also affects `load_der_public_key`: the PSS NID (912) doesn't seem to have a useful counterpart to `EVP_PKEY_get1_RSA()` used in parsing component.

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

body: Looking into this it appears there may be several missing pieces in OpenSSL. `EVP_PKEY_get0_RSA` looks for the non-PSS NID, and even if you recompile with that check removed you can't get to the RSA_PSS_PARAMS because there's no getter for `RSA_PSS_PARAMS *pss` in the opaque RSA struct. Some work is going to need to be done upstream.

This may work in 1.1.1 (which has `RSA_get0_pss_params` and knows the PSS NID for get0_RSA). 3.0 is deprecating `RSA_get0_pss_params` in favor of a new set of getters for a new `RSA_PSS_PARAMS_30` struct, but we can (likely) ignore that until such time as we're 3.0+ only: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/commit/15671090f46364a0e92456b32ead7b4714ae0b5e#diff-44d6e290c824b579440a474b82116446R41
This was actually only added in 1.1.1e and then deprecated in 3.0.0. I think we should wait for 3.0 to decide what to do here.

issue.body:
fixes #4858

also fixes #2850, albeit not completely. Iâ€™d rather see if we get future requests for encode and parameters with new issues though.

issue.title: Request: Include SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSASSA_PSS in _SIG_OIDS_TO_HASH dictionary

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
We use the cryptography module with pyWinRM to run PowerShell code on Windows systems frm a Linux environment. This works just fine, but we have a scenario that is failing because the Windows Server has a certificate using the signature algorythm RSASSA_PSS.

We can make this work by editing the oid.py file to change the dictionary:

_SIG_OIDS_TO_HASH = {
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_MD5: hashes.MD5(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_SHA1: hashes.SHA1(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID._RSA_WITH_SHA1: hashes.SHA1(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_SHA224: hashes.SHA224(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_SHA256: hashes.SHA256(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_SHA384: hashes.SHA384(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSA_WITH_SHA512: hashes.SHA512(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.ECDSA_WITH_SHA1: hashes.SHA1(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.ECDSA_WITH_SHA224: hashes.SHA224(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.ECDSA_WITH_SHA256: hashes.SHA256(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.ECDSA_WITH_SHA384: hashes.SHA384(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.ECDSA_WITH_SHA512: hashes.SHA512(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.DSA_WITH_SHA1: hashes.SHA1(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.DSA_WITH_SHA224: hashes.SHA224(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.DSA_WITH_SHA256: hashes.SHA256(),
    SignatureAlgorithmOID.RSASSA_PSS: hashes.SHA256()
}

And that resolves the issue. But is this something that can be included in the module itself rather than for us to make this change.

issue.title: Allow loading of RSA-PSS public keys

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
This does not enforce PSS constraints and instead loads them as normal
RSA public keys, similar to the support we added for private keys.

fixes #4858
